images.description: A small group of horses in a field which we passed through during our walk.The horse, known scientifically as Equus ferus caballus, is one of two subspecies of Equus ferus. We think these horses are mostlikely used for riding.

images.name: 20170722_093256.jpg
images.description: We found this rather large field of sheep on the first day of our expedition. Sheep have been resident of the UK since Roman times, and became hugely important when wool, meat, milk and skins formed the basis of Medieval trade. Today, meat is the main product of sheep, although skins, wool and milk also have their own markets.

We saw many fields of cows throughout the expedition which were of various colours and sizes depending on what type of farming they were used for. Cows were undoubtedly the most common form of livestock which we saw throughout our time around the East Grinstead area. Cows, also known as cattle, are the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are raised as livestock for meat (beef and veal), as dairy animals for milk and other dairy products, and as draft animals (oxen or bullocks that pull carts, plows and other implements). Other products include leather and dung for manure or fuel.
images.name: 20170722_134757.jpg

images.description: A couple of white geese, scientifically known as Anserini.They are classified as Waterfowl of the Anatidae family, these birds are fairly common throughout most of the UK.
images.name: 20170722_155326.jpg

images.description: We identified this species of duck to be a male Gadwall, scientifically known as Anas strepera. They come from the Anatidae family and are frequently found in the Midlands and south-east of England.
images.name: 20170722_155333.jpg

images.description: This is a species of Longhorn beetle, most likely the Tanbark Borer from the Cerambycidae family, also known as Phymatodes testaceus. This type of beetle is usually seen most from May to July and are a local species to southern England.
images.name: 20170723_114331.jpg

images.description: This species of Deer is known as the Fallow deer (scientifically known as Dama dama) and belongs to the Cervidae family. It is native to Western Eurasia but has now been introduved to other parts of the world. These deer are widespread across England and Wales but are patchy in Scotland.
images.name: 20170724_130104.jpg
